explanation: The reported issue is correct. The four statements conn_record = NULL; sock_record = NULL; sock = NULL; conn = NULL; in OS_SocketAccept are executed but removing them would not change program behaviour: the variables are only later assigned when the corresponding object-id operations succeed, and when those operations fail the variables are never dereferenced. Under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 (dead code) an operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour is dead code. Note 3 of the rule makes a distinction between initialization at the point of definition (which is not treated as a candidate for dead code) and later assignment; these four statements are assignments, not initializations at declaration, so the note does not exempt them. The comment in the source indicates they exist solely to appease static analysis tools, which exactly matches the definition of dead code. To fix this while keeping the static analyser satisfied, initialize the pointers at their declarations (e.g. OS_common_record_t *sock = NULL;) or otherwise restructure the code so that no executed assignment is redundant.
